content: The patient is a left‑hand dominant artist who lacerated the PIP joint of his left index finger on 7‑16‑25 while working with a chisel; the blade struck a hard piece of wood, slipped, and cut the finger. He presented to urgent care where the wound was irrigated and repaired. Sutures were removed approximately 14 days later, at which time the wound reopened. Since then he has experienced persistent pain and stiffness of the index finger, with limited active flexion at the PIP joint.
title: HPI Spencer

content: On exam, left upper extremity in- a laceration well-healing, um, without sutures. A very stiff index finger PIP able to flex only about 10 degrees actively at this time. Moderate soft tissue swelling, no sensory tenderness to palpation. Excellent range of motion of the remaining digit.
title: Musculoskeletal

content:
- index finger pain
- index finger stiffness
- post‑traumatic PIP stiffness
title: Assessment

content: Plan PIP recommend hand therapy. Return to clinic in four weeks for follow-up image motion.
title: Plan
